snippet: The State Department imposed a ban on visas for people who have taken steps to undermine Ukraine’s territorial integrity, and Russia vowed to reciprocate.
abstract: Crimea votes to hold referendum on whether to secede from Ukraine and become part of Russia as volatile confrontation over future of country takes another tense turn; United States imposes first sanctions on Russian officials involved in Crimea military occupation; Pres Obama and Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin hold hourlong telephone call emphasizing diplomatic settlement.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN, MICHAEL R. GORDON and ALISSA J. RUBIN
byline.contributor: David M. Herszenhorn reported from Simferopol, Michael R. Gordon from Rome, and Alissa J. Rubin from Brussels. Reporting was contributed by Peter Baker and Eric Schmitt from Washington; Ellen Barry and Steven Lee Myers from Moscow; Alan Cowell from London; Steven Erlanger from Kiev, Ukraine; Rick Gladstone from New York; Patrick Reevell from Sevastopol, Ukraine; Andrew Roth from Donetsk, Ukraine; Somini Sengupta from the United Nations; and Noah Sneider from Simferopol.

lead_paragraph: The State Department imposed a ban on visas for people who have taken steps to undermine Ukraine’s territorial integrity, and Russia vowed to reciprocate.

headline.main: Crimea Approves a Secession Vote as Tensions Rise
headline.print_headline: Crimea Approves a Secession Vote as Tensions Rise
